posts.cooked:
While Signal groups don’t require names, having a blank name looks clunky in your message view and notifications are problematic.

Could Signal just do what other messaging apps do and if there’s no group name, show the group name as a list of the contacts in that group?

I imagine this could be generated individually at the user end and as such use the local contact names.

Additionally, I think it’d be more user friendly to start group chats with the assumption there won’t be a name, then give the option to add one. It’d be a smoother experience - I know I almost never name a group message thread, I’m fine with an additional step the rare times I do.

link_counts.title: Intuitive Group Chat Creation with Member Names as Default

posts.cooked: I agree here. I have groups that I like having a name for that I communicate regularly with. I also have groups that are far more ephemeral and keeping them around causes a certain amount of clutter, especially when I’ve already deleted the conversation.

With the new group features recently added making groups more fluid and usable (awesome, very happy about them!), I think this issue has become more important. Having to name every collection of people interrupts the flow with unimportant questions, and leads to mild confusion/awkwardness later. Do I just name it after the people in it? What order do I put them in? What if there’s 10 people? If I add someone later do I have to add their name to the group title? Do I have to figure out what our shared interest is and name it after that? What if it’s nonunique, but I have separate groups with the same interest I talk to?

I often create groups for one-off or rarely-used things that aren’t worth naming, like “people who told me they were interested in ordering food tonight” or “people I was talking to about this new article in the last week”. On other messaging platforms, the majority of my groups are ad-hoc and unnamed, and I’m very happy with that.

What do the unnamed chats look like? Do they just show the list of users like MMS chats?

I have the same use case. I sometimes make chats for temporary things and I don’t really need to name them.
I feel like Signal used to default the group name to the participants at one point; am I just remembering wrong?
I believe you’re right, but I can’t remember when that changed. I personally would like that to be the default functionality if you choose to enter nothing.

posts.cooked:
I appreciate the detailed response but why even waste time with all the workarounds for such a basic function. The problem is this is how Signal was yet they CHOSE to change this. Why would they take away a choice when you can have both? That’s what is crazy to me. Give us the choice like we always had.

I understand you can type out each persons name. That’s exactly my point haha. You have to spend an obscene amount of time typing out 2-6+ peoples’ names just to send a message that takes less time that typing the names does.

iPhones don’t require you to do this in regular SMS or iMessage chats. Just add who you want. Talk. Naming it is OPTIONAL. Why take away a choice we had to make it more difficult? We can have it both ways. It’s insane, I don’t see the benefit in this change.
It’s also optional for MMS messages via Signal Android.

Yes exactly. Same for having vibration notifications only when your ringer is on. 2 things we can’t do with Signal on iPhone.

Am I missing something here? Why the hell would they deliberately take away this option ONLY for iPhone??

And why would they not allow vibration only notifications ONLY on iPhone? I don’t understand this logic but it’s literally 2 crucial functions that is forcing many of us to go use subpar apps for important messages (so we can even know we received a response), which is when we need Signal most.

They’re really giving us iPhone users a big F-you.

vandelaya:

Am I missing something here? Why the hell would they deliberately take away this option ONLY for iPhone??

They didn’t take it away only for iPhone. It just only applies to Signal groups. I’m just mentioning that creating MMS groups (on the Signal app for android) doesn’t require a name. So seems silly that they prevent the same from happening on Signal groups.

Tursko:

So seems silly that they prevent the same from happening on Signal groups.

What’s interesting is that this feature request was originally about the fact that Signal did have optional group names – specifically, if you did not supply a name, it would be blank/empty, and the request was for Signal to auto-populate the group name with the list of contact names.

So what are people asking for now? The option to leave group names blank (again)? Or for Signal to auto-generate/fill something?

Herohtar:

So what are people asking for now? The option to leave group names blank (again)? Or for Signal to auto-generate/fill something?

For it to just autofill with the names of the people on the group. Similar to how MMS groups work. I guess it doesn’t have to technically be the assigned name, but it needs to be displayed that way.

Herohtar:

So what are people asking for now? The option to leave group names blank (again)? Or for Signal to auto-generate/fill something?

At the risk of muddying the waters a bit, I’d like this feature too, but I’m specifically envisioning something iMessage-style that’s just a little beyond “allow blank group names”. Two things:

  1. Group names are optional. If not provided, default to listing the people in the group when displaying the name.
    • This means I can fire off a quick question – “What food did you want me to order?” – without breaking (mental) flow.
  2. If I start a “new” group without a name and with the exact same membership as an existing (unnamed?) group, send the message to the existing group.
    • What you talked about last can be a good conversation starter/anchor, and the context can also nudge you to consider making it a real group without forcing you to.
    • Avoids clutter in the conversation list!

I realize there are some subtleties I’m skipping over here, like “What happens if you start an unnamed group message with the same membership as an existing named group?” or “What happens if two groups have the same membership?”. Honestly, whatever iMessage has been doing all these years has been working fine, though I’m admittedly not sure exactly what that is as I haven’t intentionally explored all the scenarios.
